results.title: Sir Jack Brabham: The complete history of a motor racing legend
results.creator_credit: Neville Hay and Hay Fisher Productions
results.brief_description: Brabham - one of the great names in motor racing history. A great driver who not only became a household name worldwide during the 1950’s and 60’s for his driving exploits, but who also created a racing team that was still winning in the 1980’s. This story of Sir Jack Brabham, told exclusively in his own words and by close associates including Stirling Moss, Roy Salvadori and and John Cooper. Extensive archival material captures the feel of some glorious motor racing while tracing every step of a truly brilliant career.

results.title: Conflict of interest (D)
results.creator_credit: Tony Wellington, Ian MacArthur and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The basis of this film is the National Park and Wildlife Services kangaroo control and management program. The kangaroo is shown, historically, as a source of food for the Aborigines, as game and a source of income for the first Europeans and today as a symbol of Australia. The Kangaroo Management Program is discussed at length. It aims to ensure the conservation of all species of macropods, the investigation of agricultural damage and the best use of product derived from culling kangaroos. Statistical information on kangaroo culling is presented diagramatically.

results.title: The Miraculous Mellops 2. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Karl Zwicky, Posie Graeme-Evans, Film Australia and Millenium Pictures
results.brief_description: In this series of episodes, the Mellops family discover WOOPS or Windows of Opportunity; the only known way to travel faster than light. The alien grubs and their disgusting habits are planning to visit earth and Dump manages to steal the WOOP for his own purposes but runs into a few pointy obstacles. The adventures of the Mellops, Dumps and Grubs, takes us out of the plant nursery into outer space.

results.title: Mickey
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Rare film footage of Walt Disney introduces the long and charming life of the greatest cartoon character of them all - Mickey Mouse. Mickey started life as Mortimer, but the name just didn’t seem to fit! Instead, he became Mickey Mouse for his show business premiere on November 18, 1928. Mickey’s screen debut was in the first animated cartoon to feature synchronised sound: “Steamboat Willie”. In addition to Mickey’s first film role, this collection also includes some of his greatest adventures highlighted in a career that has spanned over 55 years. Titles include “Steamboat Willie”, “Mickey’s grand opera” and “Symphony hour”, all classics in their own right.

results.title: In the company of whales
results.creator_credit: Robin Brown, TVNZ, Channel Four Television and Discovery Networks
results.brief_description: Narrated by Jessica Tandy, this visually stunning documentary shows phenomenal encounters never before captured on film. Whales are enormous, powerful creatures with extraordinary grace and intelligence. They are masters of a watery realm where they have existed for more than 30 million years. Filmed in 15 locations off the coasts of five continents, this affords a comprehensive look at whales (Blue, Sperm, Right, Beluga, Bottle-nosed whale and their small relatives the dolphin) and their environment. Guided by one of the world’s leading Cetacean experts, Dr. Roger Payne, a team of underwater cameramen reveal the mysteries of whale song, their sophisticated navigation techniques, their remarkable intelligence and affectionate social behaviour emphasising that they really are the gentle giants of the deep.

results.title: The Birds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Talk to the animals”.
Enjoy your favourite bird stories as seen on ATN Seven’s “Talk to the animals” series with Dr. Harry Cooper. A plethora of handy hints and essential information for bird owners.

results.title: Trains remembered. - Volume 3.
results.brief_description: Ranging from the early 30’s to the late 80’s, this video utilises archival film to re-create the golden days of railway. In this volume Southern Railway trains are shown on their way to the seaside, Carlisle Station appears with electric locos followed by a collection of steam locos in 1966. Visit the Longmoor Military System in 1968, the Swindon Works in the 30’s followed by a visit in 1975 during the diesel- hydraulic era and a final visit in 1987. Witness the 150th Anniversary of the Festinog in 1986 capturing a gravity slate train in action and the 150th Anniversary of the London and Greenwich Railway in the same year. Also included is the famous Flying Scotsman from Kings Cross in 1968 and its USA trip.

results.title: Trains remembered. - Volume 2.
results.brief_description: Steam trains predominate in this unique and exciting video which features rare archival footage together with more recent material. Amongst the railway lines appearing are Little Kimble, Marlow, Colnbrook and Epping. A4’s and A2’s feature on the Kings Cross line, N2’s appear on suburban trains to Moorgate. Class 76 Electrics are shown on the Woodhead Line and in action in Holland for the last time in 1986. Witness the re-opening of the Isle of Man Steam Railway and the Kingsmoor Depot near Carlisle in 1966 which featured many steam trains.

results.title: Trains remembered. - Volume 1.
results.brief_description: Using archival footage and an informative commentary enthusiasts will be treated to a nostalgic look at the great days of railway. This volume captures steam and diesel engines dating as far back as the 1930’s including early green DMU’s, commuter trains at Liverpool Station in 1932, wartime NE A4’s and Class 78 Electrics, the Belfast 5‘3” gauge to Larne, 1950’s steam shed scenes, DEMU’s and in the 60’s KESR is taken over by the preservationists, trains at Euston, Paddington and Clapham, the last Brighton Belle, King George visits Paddington and finally a Bullied locomotive re-born in preservation.

results.title: Branchline railway
results.brief_description: Michael Palin, confessed train buff, introduces unique footage from the BBC archive: Branchline Railway and two historic newsreel sequences - a splendid requiem for the steam railway. “Branchline Railway”: the late Sir John Betjeman presents this little known film which perfectly captures the atmosphere of a 24 mile stretch of the now vanished Somerset and Dorset railway. It celebrates a working, living railway, complete with dirty locomotives, clean stations decked with flowers, and austere gas-lit waiting rooms. It all belongs to a vanished age but the film remains to delight and inform (broadcast 1963). “Britannia under her own steam” looks at the naming of the first magnificent Class 7 4-6-2 Standard locomotives ‘Britannia’ (broadcast 1951). “Atlantic Coast Express” is a footplate journey on Merchant Navy Class No. 35016 ‘Elder Fyffe’ as it heads the ‘Atlantic Coast Express’ (broadcast 1960).
